C111 GUI 2D issues.

 

 

 

 C/P111 basic tests:

 

 Important! Disconnect all cables to the TDC

 (or make sure no pulse is ever generated)!

 

 Invoke the C111GUI-1D

 

 + MODE > MHIT

 

 + Tools > self test

 

 Check (pop up) the transcript window.

 

 + Tools > memory test

 

 Check (pop up) the transcript window for errors.

 

 In the later case only a small memory area is exercised.

 For a complete memory test use next procedurre.

 

Invoke the C111GUI-2D-

 

 + Tools > self test

 

 Check (pop up) the transcript window for errors.

 

GFD, memory area :

 

Assuming a square detector,

 

(eq.1) let's have D1 and D2 the delay towards both ends of the delay line

 

(eq.2) by construction of the detector D1 + D2 = D where D is the delay line length.

 

Now let's follow the P111 procedure step by step.

 

(1)  P111 takes two measurements from an arbitrary origin (a free running counter). This yields to (notation from eq.1)

     N1 = A + D1

     N2 = A + D2  (A is the unknown origin)

 

(2)  P111 computes the difference

     Na = N2 - N1 = D2 - D1 (this eleminates A)

     At this stage we get a measurement which falls in the range

     -D < Na < +D  (because eq.2)

 

(3)  To avoid negative number P111 biases the result by adding D

 

     The final result is therefore:

     0 < Nb < 2*D

     ============

 

     (D is actually taken from the "offset register" whose value should be close to the delay line length)

   

Incidentally this shows that P111 coupled to gas-filled detector gives TWICE the position resolution that might be expected before hand.

 

Finally the P111 memory area selection can be determined depending on the choosen resolution:

full (150 ps) resolution:  0 < X,Y < 2*D(ns) / 0.150

half (300 ps) resolution:  0 < X,Y < 2*D(ns) / 0.300

 

Application example for a 150 ns delay line:

full (150 ps) resolution:  0 < X,Y < 2000

half (300 ps) resolution:  0 < X,Y < 1000

 

At times one may observe values larger than eq.2 would authorize. That's life with gas-filled detectors.

 

 

 

GFD, binning:

 

 Binning is a display (only) related facility.

 

 It consists in displaying one pixel out of two in a line and one line out of two. The display is therefore 4 times smaller, and faster. Binning is independant from the actual TDC hardware setting. In particular binning  neither impacts the TDC resolution nor the TDC memory area.

 

 

GFD, pile up rejection:

 

 When a photon hits the detector, a charge is created which propagates along the delay line, for position encoding. Should a second photon occurs closer than the delay line length, charges from both photons pile up. Both events must be rejected.

 

 The P111 TDC verify that one and only one pulse is recorded on every input for the gate duration. Otherwise this event is rejected.

 

 WARNING! Wrong offsets will also cause the P111 to reject events! Finally the P111 expect to get positive results, due to offset biasing. Otherwise (negative result) the event is rejected. Should the rejection ratio be much larger than expected, one must (among other) check the offset values. Correct offsets are close to the detector delay line length.

 For best results these values  must be optimized experimentally.

 

 

 

GFD, delay line mesurement:

 

 Let's have D1 and D2 the propagation delays towards both ends of the delay line

 By construction of the detector D1 + D2 = D where D is the delay line length.

 

 The P111 TDC may be instructed to record this sum, instead of the regular delay difference. This is a detector intrinsic characterization.

 

 To this aim, do

 

 + setting > use current configuration

 

   Check the "test" box.

   Apply the new configuration.

 

  + From the bottom bar menu, RUN TDC.

 

 The position of the central spot is a mesurement for the delay line lengths.
